notesStmt.note: Politicks in Miniature (la politique en miniature) fait la satire de l’homme politique Robert Walpole qui, à la tête de la Chambre des Communes, jouait un rôle similaire à celui de Premier ministre. Le texte a été imprimé dans un numéro du Westminster Journal de 1741, de façon anonyme, et son auteur n'a pas pu être identifié. L’avant-propos qui précède le texte utilise la métaphore répandue du theatrum mundi qui compare le monde à une scène de théâtre. Ici, le gouvernement est représenté comme une troupe de théâtre de marionnettes dont Punch est à la tête. Le personnage qu’il incarne rappelle Robert Walpole, l'homme politique du parti Whig (conservateur). L’intrigue se situe dans un contexte politique bien particulier et reflète la chute de Walpole. En 1741, lors des élections générales britanniques, le gouvernement Walpole est affaibli, même s’il conserve une mince majorité. L’année suivante, Walpole se voit contraint de poser sa démission suite à une motion de censure qui renverse son gouvernement. La pièce a été mise en scène à Londres, au Old Theatre près de Pall Mall, avec de grandes marionnettes ("rich and large figures"). Dans la plupart des éditions, le texte de Politicks in Miniature est suivi d'une arlequinade elle aussi satirique, The Political Rehearsal - Harlequin Le Grand : Or, the Tricks of Pierrot le Primier (sic), mais celle-ci semble plutôt destinée à des acteurs.

normalization.p: The semi-diplomatic norms applied are intended to guide and facilitate the reading of the original texts. The transcriptions therefore include spelling and grammatical corrections according to current standards.
The author's orthographic and grammatical corrections have been integrated into the text without being marked. Cuts for performance purposes have not been adopted in the transcription.
Syntax has been modernised where it is naturally incorrect or has become incomprehensible today. Additions are limited and indicated by square brackets.
The copyist's obvious errors (scene numbers, character attributions, etc.) have been corrected. The list of characters could also be corrected.

punctuation.p: Punctuation has been corrected according to modern rules.

projectDesc.p: Text collected during the PuppetPlays project funded by European Union (Grant Agreement 835193) under Horizon 2020. The PuppetPlays project aims to re-evaluate the contribution of the puppets repertoire to the construction of European cultural identity. Its main goals is to collect a corpus of representative plays from Western Europe (Germany, Austria, Belgium, Spain, France, Great Britain, Italy, Netherlands, Portugal, Switzerland) between the 17th and the 21th century. It also tries to identify the characteristics of puppet dramaturgy and their variations depending on eras, cultural spheres, producing conditions, and the aimed public.
This edition is the result of university research work, reviewed by the principal investigator.

div.head: Scene 1
Master of the puppet-show and Punch

sp.speaker: Master
sp.p: Vhat, Master Punch, make you in such passion ?

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: Z—ns ! All the puppets are in confederacy against me. — There are plots ; — plots in the State, Sir.

sp.speaker: Master
sp.p: Plots ! Vhat you call plots, Master Punch ?

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: I’ll tell you what I call plots. — You know I have been the hero of the stage for twenty years : I have acted the principal parts, I have diverted the public with several ingenious pranks, made heroic and witty speeches, knocked down those puppets that affronted me, kicked those off the stage that contradicted me, introduced those that complimented me. This have I reigned, with distinguished lustre, at the head of your company of wooden politicians.

sp.speaker: Master
sp.p: Vary vell, Master Punch, but vere be dis grand plot ? You have often talked of de plat, and de plot, but vere be dis plot ?

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: There are parties formed against me, and some of the puppets have been bold enough to say that I should not be at the head of the c[o]mpany any longer.

sp.speaker: Master
sp.p: Be dis de plot ! — Dis is only against you. I tought against me dat it was laid by mine puppets.

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: Why, have I not told you [a] hundred times, that is the very same thing. Witness ye Gods ! That through my sides they strike at you : they look on all my actions as yours, they know I move and have my being from you, and whatever part I play, it is with your consent.

sp.speaker: Master
sp.p: Very true. But if I command you to say dis, or do dat, shall rascally damned puppets contradict me ? Don’t dey know dat I hold de strings dat move dem about on de stage ? Dat it is I speak what you s[p]eak out ? Dat —

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: But, Sir, they say that they have felt a new kind if inspiration ; and that some God, or other, has endued them with new faculties and powers, and that they can speak and act upon new principles. Therefore, in the scenes they now play, you are to look on them not as mere pieces of wood, but as real characters.

sp.speaker: Master
sp.p: Oh ! Ho ! —Den dat — (vat you call !)— dat inspiration be de plot. And all mine puppet in dis plot ?

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: No, no : I have a strong party, as you will see soon. If you will sit down here behind the screen, you shall see such scenes played among your puppets, as will be an arrant droll.

sp.speaker: Master
sp.p: And who move de strings all dis time ?

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: You are not to imagine them wooden figures. Be a spectator of real representation, and I will begin the farce. — Whenever you think proper of speaking with us, it must be behind the screen. —

sp.speaker: Master
sp.p: —Vary vell ! — Mine show house is full of spectators : the curtain draws up, and —ha ! Ha ! Enter Master Punch for de prologue.

lg.l: Britons attend ! — nor haughtily disdain,
To view the actions of out mimic scene ;
A group of various characters it brings,
All statesmen, and all moved by secret springs.
In fiction’s guise we real truths rehearse ;
The world, and the world’s rulers prove a farce :
Nor statesmen, dare our statesmen here despise ;
As you they’re honest, and as you they’re wise.
But, laying tragic rants aside, you see
The comic her[o] of the show in me.
In me behold him who never had his fellow,
Enabled by the title Punchinello.
Long over the stage I’ve bore tyrannic sway,
And made the puppet herd power obey ;
I blustered, laughed, swore, swaggered, kicked, and then,
In humblest mood I took some kicks again.
But now behold me in an odder station,
Playing the farce of statesman’s resignation,
A scene I still shall do less good than hurt in,
Then bid you kiss my —, and drop the curtain.

sp.speaker: Master
sp.p: O rare Punch, dat vas admirably vel spoke. —Now de scene opens with Punch’s puppets. Dere be de Cockade puppets, de Blue, de Green, de Red, de Black and Vite — Vat you call dis scene, Master Punch ?

div.stage: Scene discovers Punch at his levee of puppets.

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: This is the levee. — Though there is though to be much art required to play this scene, it is not more than a woman of common beauty does every day in the drawing room.

lg.l: The Coquette, encircled round
With the fops she deigns to wound,
Shows the wisdom of the fair,
Smiling here, and ogling there ;
Raising hope, by kindly glancing ;
Seeming favours now advancing ;
All in turns expect the blessing ;
All insured of the possessing :
But the sly maid, at Love’s true call,
To some fond creature of her heart,
Who most she thinks can love impart,
Glad gives her hand, and jilts them all.
Like the art of the Coquette,
Is our conduct in the State ;
Circled by a hundred round,
Hundred little arts are found ;
Here by bowing, there assuring ;
Here by whipping, there alluring ;
All expect the favour granted ;
All sure of the place they wanted,
But find, mistaken in their friend,
The Stateman never favour gave,
But like the woman to the slave,
Who best he thought could serve his end.

sp.p: This has been my maxim from my coming into power, and I will retain it to my going out of it. Among all these there may not be five but may wish me hanged, if it was not their interest to have me at the head of them – and that can’t be long ; therefore I must manage them with all the art I am master of.

div.stage: Punch comes from the side scene towards the puppets, bowing very low to them, and they all with many cringes return the compliment.

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: I don’t remember, Sir, ever to have seen you here before.

sp.speaker: Puppet
sp.p: No, Sir, my command in the army prevented me : as I was a Lieutenant-Colonel of a Regiment, I thought it was my duty to be with it, while my Colonel was attending your Honour, and the business of P—rl—t.

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: I suppose then, good Sir, you have now a seat in the House, and have left the command to the Major, or senior Captain, or Brigadier, or Sub-Brigadier, or —or—somebody or other.

sp.speaker: Puppet
sp.p: No, Sir, I have no seat in the House : my affair is this. My Colonel is dead : I have been Lieutenant Colonel above thirty years, and in the service near fifty : I am come to solicit for this vacant Regiment, as my long and faithful services to my King and country may plead in my favour.

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: Service to you King and country, Sir ? — What services, Sir ? — Why you have no seat in the House, Sir :—I thought you might have had a seat in the House, I can’t do anything in your affair, Sir. — Nay, I don’t know but the Regiment is disposed of. —(Turns his heel from him.)Ask for a Regiment, and no member : the fellow’s mad sure !To a Ducal Puppet at his elbow

lg.l: This is just as I was told.
Hence vile reproach sullies the soldier’s fame,
And as corruption’s minion brands his name :
Rough, and experienced in war’s honoured art,
Their tongue unguileful, and unstained their heart,
Our fathers served their country and their King ;
But modern G—n’ r—ls modern talents bring :
Hence Vice our honest soldier’s fame destroys,
Ensigns are Senators, and G—n’ R—ls Boys.

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.stage: to a puppet with a star on his breast.
sp.p: And does your Grace really think of going into the army ?

sp.speaker: Puppet M
sp.p: I am determined on it. — I will be a soldier.

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: A soldier ! No, no, your grace shall be no soldier. — you shall be a General. — There is a regiment luckily just vacant.— I have been solicited for it, but — I am glad I have an opportunity to offer it your Grace.

sp.speaker: Puppet
sp.p: I am your Honour’s most humble, and most obedient servant. —I shall endeavour to return the favour.

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: I don’t doubt it. (To another puppet.) O ! Your servant, Mr Staunch. — A word with you. —I don’t know what to do about what you requested of me —for—

sp.speaker: Puppet
sp.p: For what ? I am surprised at any demurs : I never asked anything for myself. — I could not have thought after the services I have done you such a trifle —

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: Don’t mistake me : I recommended your son to the board for a Fifty-Gun Ship, but was answered he had not been a Lieutenant above a year : — What could I s[a]y ?

sp.speaker: Puppet
sp.p: What you would have said had you had a mind it should be done.

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: Well, Mr Staunch, I would not have you out of humour : your son shall be commissioned as you desire : you shall be convinced of it now. (Calls a puppet.) Chevalier Carolo, Mr Staunch’s son is, I hear, a very pretty fellow in the Navy : is there any Fifty-Gun Ship vacant ?

sp.speaker: Puppet Carolo
sp.p: Not at present ; but we shall commission some next week for that secret expedition you talked of.

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: O ! very well : give Mr Staunch the first Fifty-Gun Ship you name.

sp.speaker: Puppet Carolo
sp.p: It shall be done.

sp.speaker: Staunch
sp.p: I thank your Honour ; I knew your Honour’s power if you would exert it.

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: You’ll be at the House, Staunch ; we shall have warm work.

sp.speaker: Staunch
sp.p: Never doubt me, your Honour’s servant.

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: Plague on it, here comes a right R—vr—d Dun, which of all court duns is the most troublesome and insatiable.

sp.speaker: Puppet Lawn
sp.p: I beg your Honour’s pardon for not waiting on you as soon as I came from my diocese but I have been laid up with a fit of the gout.

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: French wine and champagne, my Lord, have strange effects, ho ! ho ! ho !

sp.speaker: Puppet Lawn
sp.p: Your Honour pleases to be merry, but in truth this election affair did compel me to exceed a little : I love, if I serve my friend, to serve him with spirit and truth.

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: Then you serve your friend better than you do your G—. (Aside) I hear, my Lord, that you remarkably distinguished yourself by your zeal.

sp.speaker: Puppet Lawn
sp.p: Sir, I exercised my pastoral authority over my flock, and dispersed circular letter to order them how they should vote : I have been threatened by the faction on this account, but I esteem myself safe enough under your Honour’s protection.

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: My Lord, you have not much to apprehend : some silly fellows may indeed say that you did not act becoming a member of the Church, that you were one of my tools, that you were a mercenary priest, and that your robes ought to be striped over your ears. Perhaps too you may be obliged to ask somebody pardon on your knees. But what’s all this ? When ‘tis over you may bid them all kiss your a—.

sp.speaker: Puppet Lawn
sp.p:
Ha ! ha ! ha ! Your Honour’s witty.
—But, please your Honour, I have news to tell you. — My Lord of —, who, you know, was of the other Party, was given over this morning by his physicians. I am sorry for my brother of — : he was a good sort of a man, but had not a right way of thinking it politics.

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: And pray what honest fellow do you know of to succeed him.

sp.speaker: Puppet Lawn
sp.p: Why, —Umph ! —Why, —ha ! ha ! ha ! — Your Honour knows that See is two thousand a year more than mine. — If your Honour thinks me a tolerably honest fellow. —Ha ! ha ! ha ! —I know your Honour likes a joke.

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: I’ll tell you, my Lord, whoever has that B—ck, must make a free-will offering of five thousand pounds to a certain female saint. If your Lordship’s orthodoxy can allow this this Saint Worship, I shall. Think you an honest fellow enough.

sp.speaker: Puppet Lawn
sp.p: Five thousand for two thousand a year : —two years and a half pays the purchase money. — I am forty-six ; —may live twenty or thirty years longer : — say seventy : —that’s twenty-four : —that’s twenty-eight thousand pounds for five. —Please your Honour your Saint may be assured of my devotion and offering.

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: And you of the B—k.(Aside) Well, this will buy Polly a pair of earrings. Oh ! Your servant, Mr Freeman, I did not see you before : have you been with P—x—n ?

sp.speaker: Puppet Freeman
sp.p: Yes, please your Honour.

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: And he has given you those papers of hints and instructions ?

sp.speaker: Puppet Freeman
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: Pray take care and write stronger : lash those factious tumultuous set of fellows, the C—t-zens of L—n : lay about you as if you were [i]n earnest.

sp.speaker: Puppet Freeman
sp.p: I shall obey your honour’s commands.

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p:
I have given P—-x—n a draught of fifteen hundred pounds for you : but out of it you must give
the fellow a hundred, who wrote the letter to a Member of Parliament.

sp.speaker: Puppet Freeman
sp.p: I will, Sir. —Damn your temper. — (Aside) Even in your extravagance you can’t forbear your old trick of quartering.

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: Have you any business with me, Sir ? Or is this only a visit of compliment ?

sp.speaker: Puppet
sp.p: Sir, my name is Merit.

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: Merit ! Merit ! — I don’t know you.

sp.speaker: Puppet
sp.p: I was recommended to you by Doctor Galen.

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: Oh ! You are the Cambridge man that is going to print some learned expensive work.

sp.speaker: Puppet
sp.p: Which I hope to have the honour to inscribe to your patronage.

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: Sir, these works of learning are of no use to me : I must be excused, you may find a more proper patron ; but as I love to encourage learned men, there’s a guinea for you. (Turns from him and goes on, followed by the other puppets.)

sp.speaker: Puppet Merit
sp.p: A Guinea ! —A single guinea ! —What a wretch ! —

lg.l: From these cursed walls with terror I will fly,
Where arts and science never come nigh :
Where the mean Sycophant, or venal slave,
Rival the honest, and supplant the brave :
To the loved banks of Cam, the muses’ seat,
Of learning and science the retreat,
Will I retire ; and, blest in my low sphere,
Leave Vice and Folly still to triumph here.

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: Now for my senatorial puppets : (Goes forward and a circle is formed.)Your servant, gentlemen. — We sat late last night.—

sp.speaker: Puppet Winni
sp.p: Had we carried your Honour’s point, we should not have grudged the hardship of the service. You find we are staunch ; not death can affright us : the Sick, the Lame – forget their diseases. Poor Mr W—lt—rs came beswaddled up in blankets ; yet all would not do : we lost the question.

sp.speaker: Puppet H—ce
sp.p:
Ay, that damned W—st—r election has done our business. Three or four thousand pounds,
Well laid out last summer, would have done more than three or fourscore thousand can now.

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: Brother, brother, that is the severest stroke we have felt : such another will compel me to quit the stage.

sp.speaker: Puppet H—ce
sp.p: Quit the stage ! What will become of me ?

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: Never fear : I have a way to bring you off safe, as well as myself.

sp.speaker: Puppet H—ce
sp.p: The Devil you have. —I am then one of the happiest dogs in England. What ! No account for my American trans..ct.ons ? No enquiry ? No refunding ?

div.stage: Enter Puppet Y— in a hurry.

sp.speaker: Puppet Y—
sp.p: Where, where’s his honour ?

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: Why such in a hurry ? Mr Secretary ? What news from the army ?

sp.speaker: Puppet Y—
sp.p: There is a desertion on your corps de reserve. The Welsh forces have openly revolted ; — but as for the Northern, I can give you no certain account of them.

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: They may try what forage they can get ; but will come back to their colours.

sp.speaker: Puppet Y—
sp.p: I have been making fine, smooth, oratorically-affecting speeches to them, and all to no purpose : you must hasten into the field of battle yourself, and try if you can rally your forces before you are entirely beat out of it.

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: A most metaphorical description of having lost the M-j-r-ty. Well, Gentlemen, all go and do your duty : this is the last public effort we can make. I have some important affairs which I must first transact in another place, but I shall meet you at Philippi.

div.stage: Exeunt Punch and his Gang separately

div.head: Scene changes
div.stage: Enter three puppets in private conference.

sp.speaker: Capt[ain] Caledon
sp.p: Look ye, Gentlemen, I am against your proposal : I will not hear of a screen.

sp.speaker: Mr English
sp.p: Nor can I approve of your Latitudunarian principles of taking all into play.

sp.speaker: Mr Worcester
sp.p: I am against carrying things to extremity. — I hate Punch as much as any of you ; but if he will voluntarily go off the stage, then his scene of action ends.

sp.speaker: Capt[ain] Caledon
sp.p: I don’t know that : we have characters which often speak from behind the scenes. In short, we do nothing, if, after we have turned him out from being an actor, we make him prompter. —The principal characters will get into his blundering way, from the blundering cues he will give them.

sp.speaker: Mr English
sp.p: Though you may cast yourselves what parts you please ; you may play the General, and you the cashier ; yet you know the master cannot bear the name of the old-fashioned, high-buskined puppets, which he calls the Tory-Rories.

sp.speaker: Capt[ain] Caledon
sp.p: Without an absolute coalition of all the company, and expelling Punch even from behind the scenes, I am determined not to act, but will only come on the stage, as Cato did into the theatre, to go out again.

sp.speaker: [Mr] Worcester
sp.p: The business of the stage must not stand still ; and I would rather play any tolerable part, than have it worse performed.

sp.speaker: Capt[ain] Caledon
sp.p: I find Punch has more interest than I imagined, and is pressing a sequel interlude behind the scenes, while we are busy on the stage.

sp.speaker: Mr English>
sp.p: Which he will call the mock-resignation.

sp.speaker: Capt[ain] Caledon
sp.p: And which will be damned, with every actor in it. —The moment therefore I see the rehearsal of it begin, I will leave the company. — You know my sentiments. Adieu.

sp.speaker: Mr English
sp.p: This difference of opinion bodes no good. I know not what to think of it.

sp.speaker: [Mr] Worcester
sp.p: I must think of playing the part I have undertaken, as well as I can. And though I appear in Punch’s place, I must not talk in the same tone.

sp.speaker: Mr English
sp.p: Nor act in the same manner ; unless you would meet with the fate Capt[ain] Caledon prognosticated.

sp.speaker: [Mr] Worcester
sp.p: Bless me ! What means this change ? I am no longer free : some secret strings pulls back my arm, another moves my tongue ; I am an errant puppet.

sp.speaker: Mr English
sp.p: Something has made a little alteration in me. I don’t move as vigorous as before. Someone behind the curtain has got playing tricks with the strings.

sp.speaker: [Mr] Worcester
sp.p: Hey Day ! Here are half the puppets come on with new motions and new faces.

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: Now, Sirs, you shall see what you shall see. — Observe that puppet, that storms and raves, and calls names : — with this little touch he is dumb. D’ye see him that stands by the scene and won’t come on. — Presto — I dispatch this [a]mbassador to him : he takes him by the hand, and he is in action immediately. — What’s that fellow talking of war ? — Here, Sir, pull this little string, and he turns about : Now, hark —

sp.speaker: A puppet
sp.p: — Negociations, if honourable, and treaties of N—tr—y may sometimes be allowed.

sp.speaker: Master
sp.p: But Punch, dat vas you dat did squeak de negotiation.

sp.speaker: Puppet
sp.p: But that is not seen by anybody but you, and therefore in the playing this whole scene, the joke lies in making them squeak my words in their own voices.

sp.speaker: Master
sp.p: Ver good shoke !

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: But you shall see a better between me and two or three puppets. (Goes and confers with puppets at the side of the stage.)

sp.speaker: Master
sp.p: Oh ! Dose be mine tr—s—ry puppets —. Vell, and vare be de shole in giving dem pieces of sticks ?

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: Why truly that may be no joke to you, but it’s a very good one to me : that very joke is worth fifty thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: Master
sp.p: I can’t find it out.

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: Oh ! That may be ; but I have made many such a joke without your finding it out. — Now, Master, you shall make a joke, and that will crown the whole farce.

sp.speaker: Master
sp.p: Ha ! ha ! ha ! Me make joke, Punch ? — Ha ! ha ! ha !

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: You shall see —. Here is my old friend Will and his wife ; and here is your old friend Punch and his daughter.

sp.speaker: Master
sp.p: And vat den ?

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: Pull that master string and try.

sp.speaker: Master
sp.p: Ha ! ha ! ha ! Good shoke indeed ! — Punch and Will turn to just as Lords, and dere wife and shild just as ladies : — Ha ! ha ! How dey strut, and de young wench and de old womans flaunt it.

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: Polly, my dear, you must now remember your rank.

sp.speaker: Puppet Pol[ly]
sp.p: I warrant you, Papa ! —

lg.l: As Lady of Qual,
I’ll flaunt in the mall,
While ‘tis said as I trip it along :
With no title Miss
A new Lady is
Old Lords and their Ladies among.
The people of rep
Blame Papa’s false step,
In ennobling the wench of his wh—
All his power must own,
For in this he has done
What was done by no subject before.
O Pol ! Should a Duke
Thy lineage rebuke,
On his own bid him ponder well rather :
If true what Fame’s told
Some Nobles — so old —
A scoundrel have had for a father.
O Polly, my dear,
The titles we’ll bear
Your Papa and my spouse have got us,
The honours we claim,
Though their loss of fame,
On them lies the censure, and not us.

div.stage: Punch assembles all the puppets around him.

lg.l: You patriots of late,
Now courtiers so great,
Of my places you’ve my resignation ;
Now courtiers, true blue,
Play your parts to cue,
What a farce will you show to the nation !
All courtiers true blue,
We’ll play to your cue,
And a farce we will show to the nation.

div.stage: Curtain drops. Enter before it : Master and Punch.

sp.speaker: Master
sp.p: Vell, dis end vid very good shoke, but vat you come now for ?

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: O ! Sir, always an epilogue to so grand a performance is expected, and I am come to speak it in form.

lg.l: Good people all, strange things we do
In this our burlesque puppet-show :
But strange as they appear to you,
They are not stranger than they’re true.
Some critics of deep penetration,
May damn our mimic resignation,
And say that our catastrophe
Does not with puppet rules agree :
Vengeance, for Punch’s crimes should catch him,
And at the last the Devil fetch him.
We have not brought this scene to view,
